Long-term holders (LTHs) are selling a large amount of Bitcoin.
Under normal circumstances, this cohort is the most bullish‚Äî
they do not sell near market bottoms and typically only begin to move closer to cycle tops.
The fact that they are selling now is therefore significant.
However, this does not necessarily imply a bearish shift.
In many cases, such selling reflects:
‚Ä¢  Planned distribution in the later stage of a cycle
‚Ä¢  Forced or necessity-driven sales
‚Ä¢  A transfer of supply to new market participants
From the strongest hands to the next strongest hands.
That is how markets have always passed the baton.

According to Crypto Rover (@cryptorover):

‚ÄúBased on the four-year cycle theory, this Bitcoin cycle already ended some time ago.‚Äù

The real divide in the market is not about direction,
but about the framework being used.

Do you view the market through cycle theory,
or through supply‚Äìdemand dynamics, liquidity, and market participants?

What‚Äôs splitting opinions right now is the interpretation of time itself.

According to Ash Crypto (@AshCrypto):

Bitcoin long positions on Bitfinex have reached their highest level since Q1 2024.
This is a sign that whales are building positions ahead of a major price move.

The last time longs accumulated to a similar level,
whales subsequently began closing their long positions, and BTC entered a parabolic rally.

This buildup of positions can be seen as
‚Äúenergy quietly accumulating beneath the surface.‚Äù
The next move could come faster and be larger than most expect.

üö® Bitcoin has dropped below $87,000

A sharp decline of roughly $4,000 within the last 60 minutes.
Thin liquidity and crowded positioning have surfaced all at once.

This move is driven less by a breakdown in fundamentals,
and more by liquidations and supply‚Äìdemand adjustments.
The market has entered a phase of peak volatility.

Bitcoin surged by about $3,300 in just 30 minutes,
liquidating roughly $106 million in short positions.

Soon after, it reversed sharply‚Äîfalling around $3,400 within 45 minutes,
this time liquidating approximately $52 million in long positions.

This is not healthy trend formation,
but rather back-and-forth moves designed to hunt liquidity.

Rather than simply ‚Äúhigh volatility,‚Äù
this is a market where positions themselves are being targeted.
At this stage, short-term supply‚Äìdemand dynamics and leverage management matter far more than direction.

Eight Hours, One Shock and a Familiar Pattern

In the past eight hours, roughly $120 billion vanished from the crypto market. Not through a single event, but through a rapid unwinding positions closing, leverage snapping, conviction being tested.

Moments like this feel chaotic on the surface. Prices drop fast, timelines fill faster, and emotions run hotter than data. But underneath the volatility, the market is doing what it always does in stress: forcing decisions.

Liquidations don‚Äôt just erase value they rearrange ownership. Weak positions exit, risk resets, and capital migrates to hands willing to sit through discomfort. This is the part of the cycle few enjoy, but every cycle passes through.

The real story isn‚Äôt the number itself.
It‚Äôs what happens after the dust settles who left, who stayed, and who quietly stepped in while attention was fixed on the fall.

So the question is: are you watching the red candles‚Ä¶ or watching how the market is reshaping itself right now?

#Crypto #CryptoMarket

It was crypto entering the macro system ‚Äî where liquidity, rates, and regulation matter more than narratives.

Can Bitcoin really break $100K before we enter 2026? That question keeps coming up, and honestly, the signals right now are more nuanced than most headlines make them sound.

On one side, prediction markets aren‚Äôt fully convinced. The odds are mixed, which tells me the market isn‚Äôt pricing in a guaranteed breakout. There‚Äôs hesitation, uncertainty, and a lot of ‚Äúwait and see‚Äù behavior. But that‚Äôs not necessarily bearish. Historically, Bitcoin doesn‚Äôt make its biggest moves when everyone agrees, it moves when expectations are divided and positioning is light.

Macro factors are quietly doing a lot of work in the background. Inflation data, Federal Reserve policy, and overall liquidity conditions are shaping risk appetite. The Fed isn‚Äôt aggressively tightening, and while rates and inflation remain key variables, the pressure isn‚Äôt as extreme as past cycles. This creates a fragile but supportive environment where risk assets can breathe if conditions tilt even slightly positive.

Then there‚Äôs the ETF factor. Spot Bitcoin ETFs have changed the structure of demand. These flows aren‚Äôt driven by hype or social media narratives; they reflect longer-term allocation decisions. When ETF inflows stay consistent, they act like a slow, steady bid under price, and that‚Äôs often how major levels eventually give way.

So will Bitcoin hit $100K before 2026? It‚Äôs not guaranteed, and prediction markets reflect that uncertainty. But between steady ETF demand, macro conditions that aren‚Äôt outright hostile, and a market that feels more tired than euphoric, the setup is quietly interesting.

Big Bitcoin moves don‚Äôt usually arrive with excitement.
They arrive when conviction is low, and patience runs out.

That‚Äôs what makes this phase worth watching closely.
